title: Question 6
prompt: <u>I walked to the store. I bought some milk.</u>
description: Read the underlined sentences. Then choose the sentence that combines those sentences into one.
feedback: The difference between the answer choices is the conjunction used to join the two sentences. Should it use “for,” “or,” “and,” or “so”? The two sentences describe two separate things that the speaker did: walked to the store and bought some milk. The conjunction “for” is not correct because it shows cause and effect. The conjunction “or” shows a choice, so it is also incorrect. The conjunction “so” also shows cause and effect, so it’s not appropriate. The best choice is “and,” which simply shows that two things happened.
